CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Violation of Art. 13+6-1;Remainder inadmissible;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - award

TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . The applicant worked for a ORG - owned theatre in GPE ( GPE NORP ORG PERSON , “ the employer ” ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE she was dismissed and initiated court proceedings to have that dismissal annulled . On DATE ORG ordered her re - instatement . Following the employer 's refusal to abide by the court order , she complained to ORG ( “ the NORP ” ) on DATE . On CARDINAL MarchCARDINAL the Ministry assured her that the employer would abide by the judgment , failing which it would take action .

CARDINAL . The applicant was re - instated on DATE . Notwithstanding that fact , another person continued to be mentioned in the staff lists as chief accountant . On DATE ORG quashed the lower court 's judgment . It delivered its reasoned decision DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was again dismissed from her job . She continued to complain to various authorities , including the Ministry . On CARDINAL DATE ORG quashed ORG judgment of DATE and upheld the judgment of CARDINAL DATE . On DATE the order of DATE dismissing the applicant was annulled ; at the same time she was again dismissed .

On DATE the Deputy President of ORG informed the regional prosecutor about the employer 's persistent resistance and the resulting failure to properly enforce the judgment of DATE . Moreover , the prosecutor was informed of the applicant 's further dismissal on DATE . In the light of these events , the court requested the prosecutor to open a criminal investigation against the employer 's director .

CARDINAL . The applicant continued to complain about the incomplete enforcement of the judgment of DATE . On DATE she was informed by ORG of an administrative fine imposed on the theatre director on DATE , and of the request to open a criminal investigation against him . The employer submitted to the court another order , dated DATE , annulling the applicant 's dismissal of DATE . On DATE a bailiff confirmed that the applicant had not been de facto re - instated in the specific prior position . On CARDINAL DATE the President of ORG requested the prosecutor to open a criminal investigation against the theatre director for failure to enforce the judgment of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was dismissed from the post of superior accountant . On the same date the court informed ORG employer 's persistent refusal to enforce the judgment of DATE . On an unknown date the employer presented a new order , dated DATE , in accordance with which the position of “ chief accountant ” no longer existed . On DATE the court again asked the prosecutor to initiate criminal proceedings against the theatre director . It also informed ORG employer 's failure to enforce the court judgment in the applicant 's favour in a proper manner . The Ministry drew the employer 's attention to the need to abide by the judgment .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG annulled the dismissal order of CARDINAL DATE and ordered the applicant 's immediate re - instatement .

CARDINAL . On DATE the employer adopted a new order ( “ the first order of DATE ” ) whereby the applicant was re - instated in the position of “ superior accountant ” . On DATE the bailiff confirmed that the judgment had not been properly enforced and on DATE he asked the court to impose an administrative fine on the theatre director .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecution informed the applicant that its verification revealed a failure to properly enforce the judgment of CARDINAL DATE and that the employer 's order of DATE had been challenged in court .

CARDINAL . On DATE the employer adopted a new order to the effect that the position of “ chief accountant ” would no longer exist after DATE . On DATE the applicant was informed that a new order dated DATE ( “ the second order of CARDINAL DATE ” ) had been adopted , under the same number as the previous order of that date ( see paragraph DATE above ) , re - instating her in her original position as chief accountant . She was also warned that that position would end on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment of DATE . By another decision of the same date the court rejected the bailiff 's request to impose a fine on the theatre director .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested the employer to issue an order whereby the position of chief accountant would be “ created in reality ” and reflected in the official documents ( state de personal ) since no such position allegedly existed officially , apart from her re - instatement order . She also asked to be given the necessary authorities and access to documents in order to perform her functions .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the decision of DATE not to impose a fine on the theatre director . It ordered a re - hearing of the case .
CARDINAL . The applicant initiated new court proceedings , seeking to have the order of DATE annulled as unlawful .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to declare invalid the first order of DATE ( order no . CARDINAL , re - instating her in the position of superior accountant , see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , and to declare valid the other order with the same number and date ( order no . CARDINAL , re - instating her in the position of chief accountant , see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . On DATE ORG quashed that judgment and simultaneously adopted a new one , which also annulled the first order and upheld the second . On DATE the ORG quashed both judgments and ordered a full re - hearing .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the re - instatement of the applicant in the position of chief accountant . On DATE the ORG quashed that judgment and discontinued the proceedings in respect of the annulment of the order of DATE , stating that the decision to abolish a position - taken in accordance with the relevant procedure - was an internal matter for the theatre and was not subject to judicial control . The court also ordered a re - hearing of the case in respect of the annulment of the order of CARDINAL DATE , the applicant 's de facto re - instatement and payment of her salary for the duration of her involuntary absence from work . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's appeal against the discontinuation of proceedings with regard to the annulment of the order of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG discontinued the proceedings in respect of the annulment of the order of DATE and the de facto re - instatement of the applicant because the proceedings had been incorrectly initiated as civil proceedings , whereas they were within the competence of the administrative courts . On DATE ORG dismissed the bailiff 's proposal to fine the theatre director for failure to enforce the judgment of DATE . This latter decision was subsequently upheld by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant inquired about the reasons for the non - enforcement of the judgment of DATE . It appears that she did not receive any reply . She repeated her request on DATE , when she was informed about the decisions of DATE . She then appealed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG quashed the first of the CARDINAL decisions of DATE ( regarding discontinuation of the proceedings for lack of competence ) and ordered a re - hearing of the case . The court found that the parties had not been informed about the hearing and had not been sent a copy of the decision and , further , that the case file had not been received at the registry of the lower court until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG found that the applicant 's re - instatement had been ordered CARDINAL times by final court judgments ( on DATE , DATE and DATE ) and that she had been properly re - instated on DATE ; it therefore dismissed her claim for re - instatement . The court left unexamined her request for compensation for the effects of inflation on the late payment and her claim for non - pecuniary damage , which could be examined in separate proceedings .

CARDINAL . The applicant submitted that she was not informed of her employer 's order of CARDINAL DATE , had not acknowledged receipt of the order as required by law , and was thus unable to challenge it in court . The order had not been presented to the courts or to any other authority in any of the proceedings after DATE , which meant that it was fake .

CARDINAL . CARDINAL . The applicant submitted medical evidence concerning several periods of in - patient hospital treatment during the proceedings and claimed that she had spent a considerable amount of money on treatment for herself and her daughter .

CARDINAL . According to a letter from ORG to ORG , dated DATE , the applicant 's appeal was sent to ORG on DATE . CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment of DATE . That judgment was also upheld by ORG on DATE and thus became final .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW , in force before DATE , read :
“ LAW
Court judgments are immediately enforceable if they order the defendant to :
... ( CARDINAL ) pay [ an employee ] his / her salary ...
... ( CARDINAL ) re - instate in his / her job an unlawfully dismissed worker . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the new Code of Civil Procedure read :
“ Article CARDINAL .
... ( CARDINAL ) Court actions regarding ... work related claims ... shall be examined urgently and on a priority basis .
Article CARDINAL
( CARDINAL ) Court decisions and judgments are immediately enforceable if they order the defendant to :
... d ) pay compensation for involuntary absence from work , when the person is re - instated in his or her job .
( CARDINAL ) Court judgments regarding re - instatement in post of those unlawfully dismissed or transferred shall be enforced immediately . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW ( in force at the time ) read :
“ Article CARDINAL .

An employee may apply to the labour disputes commission or a court directly within DATE from the date on which he or she discovered or ought to have discovered the violation of his or her rights . Where an employee is dismissed , DATE is counted from DATE on which the dismissal order was announced to him or her and was acknowledged by the employee 's signature . ”
